Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Citizen Science Assists a Novel Measurement of Mass-Loss Rates and Extends the Galactic Census of Runaway Massive Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stars with masses much greater than that of our Sun are the engines that drive the evolution of our galaxy, mixing the interstellar gas and dust with their winds, radiation, and eventually their violent deaths in supernova explosions. The rate at which these massive stars lose matter is an important quantity in determining how these stars evolve near the ends of their lives. There are, however, large uncertainties in the measurements of mass-loss rate for these stars with major discrepancies between theoretical and observational results. The goal of this project is to measure mass loss from massive stars through a unique program that involves "citizen science" called Zooniverse.

This project will use the Zooniverse citizen science program to enable thousands of non-scientists to comb through recently completed Spitzer and WISE space telescope surveys in search of bow shock nebulae. These bow shock nebulae are indicative of runaway massive stars ejected from their stellar birthplaces. It is expected that the citizen scientists will identify approximately 300 massive stars through their bow shock structure. These identifications will be followed up by spectroscopic measurements with the 2.3m Wyoming Infrared Observatory (WIRO) in order to derive mass-loss rates, which will result in a statistically compelling sample of objects for comparison with theoretical models.

Both PIs are heavily involved in the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, and the proposed work will further strengthen the students' exposure to astronomical research. The observations with WIRO telescope will foster mutually beneficial exchanges between the urban, predominantly Hispanic undergraduate institution Cal Poly Pomona and the rural University of Wyoming through hands-on observational astronomy and data analysis. The Cal Poly Pomona proposal in this collaboration is a Research in Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) project, which will offer numerous opportunities to train new scientists with a strong emphasis on recruiting students from underrepresented groups into STEM fields. This project will also initiate a Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program at WIRO that will pair secondary science teachers with University of Wyoming faculty and summer Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) program students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A team of researchers at Cal Poly Pomona and the University of Wyoming has conducted the largest survey to date for an exotic class of astronomical objects known as infrared stellar-wind bow shock nebulae. These nebulae are produced by some of the most massive, powerful stars in our Milky Way Galaxy. Studying the properties of these bow shocks should yield new insights into the powerful but enigmatic winds of these stars—the progenitors of supernovae, neutron stars and black holes and the main drivers of galaxy evolution across the universe.

The search began with a dozen students visually inspecting survey images from two satellite observatories, the Spitzer Space Telescope and Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, and culminated with a 9-month effort involving nearly 9,000 "citizen scientists" who identified and marked possible bow shocks while sifting through more than 75,000 images provided through the online Milky Way Project interface. In the end, 956 high-quality bow shock candidates were identified by these searches, expanding the previous lists of these objects by a factor of 10.

Student researchers also performed follow-up observations of candidate bow shock driving stars using ground-based telescopes, primarily the 2.3-m WIRO telescope maintainted by the university of Wyoming. These observations confirmed that 90% of the bow shock nebulae were indeed produced by massive stars.

The team of student researchers involved with this project was large and diverse, comprising one graduate student and 16 undergraduates drawn from Cal Poly Pomona, University of Wyoming, and several other US colleges and universities. These students learned astronomical observing techniques, computer programming and data analysis skills. Among the undergraduate researchers who have since earned their Bachelor's degrees, two have gone on to post-graduate studies in astronomy, one is completing a teacher-certification program, and one secured a position as a systems engineer at a major US Aerospace corporation.

This research has provided valuable technical training for the next-generation US workforce while engaging a large world-wide community of non-scientist volunteers in the excitement of astronomical research.
